questions.text: Which of the following is not expected to increase as an immediate response to surgical stress or trauma?
questions.solution:
Insulin levels in plasma are decreased in the immediate ebb phase of surgical stress or trauma.

There are three phases in the physiological response to injury:

  • Ebb phase
  • Flow phase
  • Recovery phase.

The ebb phase begins at the time of injury and is characterized by hypovolemia and decreased basal metabolic rate. The predominant hormones regulating the ebb phase are catecholamines, cortisol, and aldosterone. 

The following mechanism leads to a reduction in insulin secretion during this phase:

Pro-inflammatory cytokines like interleukin-1, tumour necrosis factor α, IL-6 and IL-8 are produced within the first 24 hours of injury.

In the later flow phase, insulin secretion begins to normalize i.e., relatively increases. However, insulin resistance by target cells occurs because of a defect in the insulin receptor/intracellular signalling pathway.

Thus, the perioperative period is characterized by a state of functional insulin deficiency.

Related Pearl: Response to surgical stress / trauma :

Factors that are altered in cases of trauma or surgical stress:

Increased levels Decreased levels
  • ACTH
  • Cortisol
  • Adrenaline
  • Glucagon
  • GH
  • TNF α
  • IL-1
  • IL-6
  • IL-8
  • Insulin (ebb phase)
  • IGF-1
  • Testosterone
  • T3

Metabolic changes seen include:

  • ↑ Adipocyte lipolysis
  • ↑ Hepatic gluconeogenesis
  • ↑ Skeletal muscle protein degradation
  • ↑ Hepatic acute phase protein synthesis
  • Pyrexia
  • Hypermetabolism

questions.text:
Following a mass casualty, how would you triage the following patients?
Patient Triage color code
1) A patient with tension pneumothorax A) Black
2) A patient with 95% third-degree burns B) Red
3) A patient with a laceration on the forehead C) Yellow
4) A patient with a degloving injury D) Green
questions.solution:
The patients should be triaged as follows:

Patient Triage color code
A patient with tension pneumothorax Red
A patient with 95% third-degree burns Black
A patient with a laceration on the forehead Green
A patient with a degloving injury Yellow

Triage means 'to sort'. It is done to categorize the need for priority of patients in cases of mass casualties.

START triage scheme stands for Simple Triage And Rapid Treatment.

Triage comes from the French word 'trier' which means 'to separate or select'. It was first used during the Napoleonic wars in the 1800s. It is of importance to note that advanced triage has ethical implications since treatment is intentionally delayed for some patients.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text:
The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
  1. Glasgow coma scale
  2. Respiratory Rate
  3. Pulse Rate
  4. Systolic BP
  5. Mechanism of Injury
questions.solution:
The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient.

Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

The score range is 0–12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man sustained a roller crush injury of his left arm up to mid-humerus and was brought to the casualty. The duty orthopedician uses the MESS score to decide about limb salvage. The score does not include which of the following?

questions.text: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is being done in a patient with suspected hemoperitoneum. Which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Presence of more than 100,000 RBCs/mm3 is a positive finding
Presence of more than 200 white cells/mm3 is a positive finding
Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy
Amylase levels more than 175 units/dL is a positive finding

questions.solution:
The presence of more than 500 white cells/mm3 in blunt trauma indicates a positive finding of diagnostic peritoneal lavage.

Diagnostic peritoneal lavage detects the presence of intraperitoneal blood. Its use has decreased to virtually nil at many centres with the advent of the FAST examination.

Indications for diagnostic peritoneal lavage are:

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Low abdominal rib fractures
  • Unexplained hypotension
  • Spinal or pelvic fractures
  • Paraplegia or quadriplegia
  • Assessment hampered by altered mental status due to neurologic injury or intoxication.

Procedure:

It is performed through a small infraumbilical incision with the placement of the catheter under direct vision. The supraumbilical approach is indicated in pregnant patients and those with pelvic fractures. Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy.

If no blood is aspirated, a catheter is placed and 1 L of Ringer lactate solution is instilled into the peritoneal cavity and then allowed to drain by gravity. At least 200 mL of lavage fluid should be recovered to allow for accurate interpretation.

Disadvantages:

  • Neither qualitative nor quantitative
  • Cannot identify the source of hemorrhage
  • Relatively small amounts of intraperitoneal bleeding may result in a positive study
  • May not detect small and large injuries to the diaphragm
  • Cannot rule out injury to the bowel or retroperitoneal organs.

questions.text: A 32-year-old professional boxer was brought to the emergency department following a blow to the abdomen. On examination, his vitals were normal, and his abdomen was tender on palpation. Which among the following is the best modality to assess the injury to the abdominal organs for this patient?
questions.solution:
A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the best diagnostic modality (gold standard) for stable patients with blunt trauma to the abdomen.

It is a non-invasive and sensitive investigation. It can identify haemorrhage, intraabdominal as well as retroperitoneal organ injury. However, performing CECT is time-consuming (when compared to FAST) and therefore it can be used only in stable patients.

FAST ultrasound is a limited examination directed to look for intraperitoneal fluid or pericardial injury as a marker of the underlying injury. The best imaging modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is FAST.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the trauma unit following a road traffic accident. He is hemodynamically unstable. As an adjunct to the primary survey, the managing surgeon decides to do a FAST. Which of the following areas would not be visualized in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The left lower quadrant is not assessed in FAST examination.

FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries.

FAST also stands for Focussed abdominal sonography for trauma. However, since FAST is not only used to assess abdominal injuries but also to assess haemopericardium in cases of pericardial injuries, the expansion Focussed assessment with sonography for trauma is preferred. It can be performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique of FAST examination:

With the patient in the supine position, a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used.

Four regions may be scanned:

  • Subxiphoid transverse view - To assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
  • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant - To assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morrison's pouch.
  • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant - To assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury.
  • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region - To assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas.

In an extended FAST or eFAST scan, left and right thoracic views are used to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique?

choices.text: Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis
Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis → Pericardial sac
Pelvis → Pericardial sac → Perisplenic region → Perihepatic region
Perisplenic region → Perihepatic region → Pericardial sac → Pelvis

questions.solution: The correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique is Pericardial sac → Perihepatic region → Perisplenic region → Pelvis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of blunt trauma is brought to the casualty and an eFAST examination is performed. Which of the following statements about the investigation is false?

choices.text: B-lines indicate a normal ultrasonographic finding of the lung
Stratosphere sign seen in M-mode USG is indicative of pneumothorax
It can be reliably used to detect less than 100 mL of free blood
It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
FAST is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.

Disadvantages of FAST:

  • Does not directly identify injury to hollow viscus
  • Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma
  • Unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

B-lines or "comet trails" are echogenic bright linear reflections beneath the pleura that are usually lost with any air between the probe and the lung tissue.

B-lines’ are expected in normal aerated lung and are visualized moving along with the sliding pleura. Excessive ‘B-lines’, especially in the anterior lung, are abnormal and are usually indicative of interstitial edema.

Therefore, the presence of B-lines along with seashore sign indicates the absence of pneumothorax. The image below shows the seashore sign.

Barcode sign which is also known as the stratosphere sign and lack of sliding movement in the lungs diagnosed by an M-mode USG is suggestive of pneumothorax.

questions.text:
An intensivist is evaluating a patient for brain stem death in the ICU. Presence of which of the following features should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal brainstem function in this patient?
  1. Babinski reflex
  2. Decorticate and decerebrate posturing
  3. Tachycardia
  4. Normal systolic BP > 100 mm Hg
  5. Positive oculo-cephalic reflex
questions.solution:
Babinski reflex, tachycardia, and normal systolic blood pressure can be occasionally seen in patients with brain stem death. So, this should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal brainstem function

Brain death is not characterized by decerebrate or decorticate posturing, which is a brain-originating motor response.

Brainstem death is defined as the irreversible loss of cerebral and brain-stem function.

Ideal criteria for brain stem death contain three essential elements: 
  • Widespread cortical destruction that is reﬂected by deep coma and unresponsiveness to all forms of stimulation
  • Global brainstem damage demonstrated by absent pupillary light reaction and by the loss of oculovestibular and corneal reﬂexes
  • Destruction of the medulla manifested by complete and irreversible apnea.

Brainstem death entails testing twice, by two clinicians, to demonstrate the absence of:

  • Response to pain
  • Respiratory drive (apnea despite arterial PCO2 ≥ 60 mm Hg )
  • Pupillary light reflex
  • Corneal reflex
  • Vestibulo-ocular reflex
  • Oculo-cephalic reflex

The following manifestations are occasionally seen in brain dead patients and should not be misinterpreted as evidence for brainstem function:

  • Normal systolic blood pressure >100 mmHg
  • Movements originating from the spinal cord or peripheral nerve may occur
  • Sweating, flushing, tachycardia
  • Deep tendon reflexes, superficial abdominal reflexes, triple flexion response
  • Babinski reflex
  • Spontaneous movements of limbs other than pathologic flexion or extension response
  • Respiratory-like movements (shoulder elevation and adduction, back-arching, intercostal expansion without significant tidal volumes).

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient?

choices.text: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan
All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
X-ray of the pelvis is essential in primary survery
X-rays in primary survey must also be done in pregnant women

questions.solution:
Chest X-ray and X-ray pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a trauma patient.

Related Pearl: ATLS Primary Survey

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

Primary Survey: ABCDEs of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) - If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment - maintain adequate oxygenation, consider non-invasive or invasive ventilation when indicated
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage, maintain circulating volume and adequate end-organ perfusion) - Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment - perform a basic neurologic evaluation (AVPU/GCS-P), blood glucose levels
  • Exposure with environmental control - undress the patient and examine thoroughly for possible injuries, prevent hypothermia

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood collection - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done on pregnant women.
  • (e)FAST

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.solution:
Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

Primary survey identifies and manages the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. 

The secondary survey includes investigations that help identify all other injuries, excluding the apparent ones. This includes X-rays of the spine and extremities and a CT of the abdomen, head, chest, and spine.

questions.text: A patient who sustained an RTA was brought to the ER in a semiconscious state. He makes incoherent sounds, withdraws from painful stimuli, and opens his eyes to painful stimuli. Calculate his GCS score.
questions.solution:
The GCS score in this patient is 8.

Withdraws from pain = 4

Incoherent sounds = 2

Opens eyes to painful stimuli = 2

Total GCS score = 4 + 2 + 2 = 8.

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered balanced resuscitation?

choices.text: Maintain ph by ensuring acid-base balance
Fluid resuscitation by giving colloids and crystalloids

questions.solution:
Permissive hypotension is a part of balanced resuscitation in trauma management to avoid bleeding.

Damage control resuscitation (DCR) i.e. balanced resuscitation is used in the settings of major trauma. It aims to control hemorrhage and prevent coagulopathy prior to the development of the trauma triad of death (hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy). The components of DCR include:

  • Permissive hypotension until definitive surgical control 
  • Minimize crystalloid based resuscitation
  • Early use of blood products (PRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitate) in the ratio of 1:1:1
  • Use of hemostatic agents such as tranexamic acid, recombinant factor 7a, prothrombin complex concentrates

DCR has the following advantages:

  • Minimizes the impact of trauma-induced coagulopathy
  • Limits blood product waste
  • Reduces the complications that occur with aggressive crystalloid resuscitation.

  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage, maintain circulating volume and adequate end-organ perfusion) - Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs have a significant role in the mortality reduction of trauma patients based on the CRASH-2 trial?
questions.solution: The CRASH-2 trial has shown mortality reduction in bleeding trauma patients by early usage of tranexamic acid (preferably within the first 3 hours) with a loading dose of 1 g over 10 minutes and then infusion of 1 g over 8 hours.

questions.text:
In a patient with massive haemorrhage, damage control surgery is being performed. What does this consist of?
  1. Arrest of hemorrhage
  2. Sepsis control
  3. Protection from further injury
  4. Performing immediate definitive repair
  5. Administering colloids for volume expansion
questions.solution:
Damage Control Surgery refers to performing limited surgical intervention in order to arrest hemorrhage, control sepsis, and protect from further injury.

This concept of tailoring the operation to match the patient’s physiology and staged procedures to prevent physiological exhaustion is called Damage Control Surgery.

Furthermore, definitive repairs are delayed and not until the patient is hemodynamically stable and physiologically capable of sustaining the procedure. Crystalloid and colloid infusions are limited in order to avoid dilutional coagulopathy.

The term Damage Control Surgery is borrowed from the military, which ensures the continued functioning of a damaged ship above conducting complete repairs which would prevent a rapid return to battle.

questions.text: A young man sustained multiple injuries following a road traffic accident. On examination, his pulse rate is 100/min and BP is 85/60 mmHg. He is diagnosed with pelvic fracture and is suspected to have retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of damage control surgery
Definitive repair of injuries is done 12-24 hours after phase III
Internal iliac artery ligation is done in phase II
Hypothermia and acidosis are corrected in phase I

questions.solution:
Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of Damage Control Surgery.

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

It consists of three phases:

  1. Phase I - Initial Exploration: This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active haemorrhage and contamination.
  2. Phase II - Secondary Resuscitation: This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis.
  3. Phase III - Definitive Operation: It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the trauma triad of death?
questions.solution:
Shock is not considered to be a component of the trauma triad of death.

The trauma triad of death is a combination of clinical features that are seen in exsanguinating trauma patients and contribute to the majority of trauma-related mortality and morbidities. The triad includes:

  • Hypothermia
  • Coagulopathy
  • Acidosis

During the resuscitation phase of trauma, adequate precautions should be taken to prevent the development of these features.

  • Hypothermia is prevented by maintenance of ambient temperature within the patient’s room, usage of prewarmed iv fluids, blankets, etc.
  • Coagulopathy can be prevented by judicious use of i.v crystalloids (<1-1.5 Lit), early initiation of blood and blood products, usage of tranexamic acid, etc.
  • Acidosis can be prevented by correction of shock, ensuring adequate oxygenation, usage of sodium bicarbonate, etc.
